items.title: Extra Extra: NYC is still the city that never sleeps
items.description: Because running for the subway keeps us moving, here are your afternoon links: Valentine's Day plans, new tech job market hack, Meta forcing users to see political content, and more from around the city and internet.

image.title: GettyImages-2185779834.jpg
image.alt: Talib Kweli performs at the New York Public Radio 2024 Centennial Gala
image.credit: Astrid Stawiarz/Getty Images for New York Public Radio

items.title: Mayor Adams unveils $650 million homelessness and mental health plan in State of the City
items.description: The annual speech could be the last for Adams, who is fighting federal corruption charges while running for re-election.

image.title: Adams-SOTCgetty.jpg
image.alt: Mayor Eric Adams speaks at a microphone
image.caption: Mayor Eric Adams gave his fourth State of the City address on January 9, 2025.

related_authors.biography: Elizabeth Kim is a reporter on the People and Power desk who covers mayoral power. She previously covered the pandemic, housing, redevelopment and public spaces. A native of Queens, she speaks fluent Mandarin. Got a tip? Email elkim@nypublicradio.org

Brigid Bergin is an award-winning senior reporter on the People and Power desk. She is fiercely committed to telling stories that help people engage and support democracy. In 2022, she hosted a live, ten-week call-in politics show ahead of the midterm elections called The People's Guide to Power. Brigid's reporting in 2017 included some of the first coverage of a political newcomer now known as AOC. In 2016, she broke the news of a voter purge in Brooklyn just days before New York’s presidential primary, triggering city, state and federal investigations. Brigid also guest hosts The Brian Lehrer Show and All Of It. She graduated from the University at Albany and the CUNY Newmark School of Journalism. Got a tip? Email bbergin@wnyc.org or Signal 917-723-4719.

items.title: Albany already revising new antipollution law after gas industry pushback
items.description: The measure became law only weeks ago, but amendments are expected in the current legislative session.

image.title: superfund.jfif
image.alt: Protesters holding signs about "greedy oil companies."
image.caption: Protesters rallying in support of the climate superfund law in 2023.

related_authors.biography: Rosemary is health & science reporter. Got a tip? Email rmisdary@nypublicradio.org or Signal 646-544-9524.

items.title: Got a late fee for NYC congestion pricing already? It's a scam.
items.description: The MTA says it will not charge any fines or fees besides the toll price for 60 days. Watch out for phishing scams.

image.title: GettyImages-2192290715.jpg
image.alt: A sign telling New York City drivers they're in the "Congestion Relief Zone."
image.caption: Congestion pricing is now in effect in New York City — but fees and fines don't start for 60 days.
image.credit: Lokman Vural Elibol/Anadolu via Getty Images

items.title: Poet wanted: Newark now accepting applications for its first-ever poet laureate
items.description: The position comes with a $5,000-a-year honorarium, according to the city.

image.title: GettyImages-1472393116.jpg
image.alt: A man in a blue knit cap and burgundy suit with a purple tie smiles outside in front of a crowd.
image.caption: Ras Baraka, the mayor of Newark, announced the job posting on Tuesday.

items.title: Early Addition: Crooners who sing Frank Sinatra songs at Long Island senior centers are thriving
items.description: Because luck be a lady, here are your early links: Staten Islanders take the ferry because of congestion pricing, we haven't had a massive snowstorm in almost a decade, norovirus is here and more.

image.title: impersonator.jpg
image.alt: a Frank Sinatra impersonator performing for seniors
image.credit: Craig F. Walker/The Denver Post via Getty Images

items.title: Former Rikers officer pleads guilty to smuggling illegal drugs into jail for bribes
items.description: Federal prosecutors say the officer was caught by a drug-detecting dog on her way into work last year.

image.title: b1.jpg
image.alt: Cash and drugs prosecutors say were found in the possession of former city correction officer Ghislaine Barrientos in 2024
image.caption: Cash and drugs prosecutors say were found in the possession of former city correction officer Ghislaine Barrientos in 2024
image.credit: U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York

related_authors.biography: Brittany Kriegstein covers all breaking news around New York City, with a focus on crime and gun violence. Got a tip? Email Brittany at bkriegstein@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: After latest NYC real estate controversy, councilmember calls for fresh look at city brokers
items.description: City Councilmember Lincoln Restler said the city should consider working with new brokerages after a lawsuit accusing its top real estate official of favoritism.

image.title: GettyImages-881041878 (1).jpg
image.caption: Jesse Hamilton in 2017.
image.credit: Photo by Andy Katz/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

related_authors.biography: David is a reporter covering housing for Gothamist and WNYC. Got a tip? Email dbrand@nypublicradio.org or Signal 908-310-3960.

items.title: NY immigration and housing groups, girding for Trump, offer their own policy protections
items.description: The groups, including family and supportive housing provider Win, want stronger “sanctuary city” protections, more housing and legal help for migrants.

image.title: GettyImages-1490424455.jpg
image.alt: Newly arrived asylum-seekers wait in a holding area at the Port Authority bus terminal in this May 15, 2023, file photo.
image.caption: Newly arrived asylum-seekers wait in a holding area at the Port Authority bus terminal in this May 15, 2023, file photo.

related_authors.biography: Arya is a reporter covering race and justice. Got a tip? Email: asundaram@nypublicradio.org or reach Arya on Signal at 512-650-8767.

items.title: Thief steals $300 from St. John’s University church in Queens, NYPD says
items.description: Police say an unidentified individual stole $300 in cash from a church on the St. John’s University campus.

related_authors.biography: Phil Corso is the evening news editor at WNYC/Gothamist. Got a tip? Email pcorso@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: Subway track worker collapses, dies on the job in Brooklyn, union says
items.description: The Transport Workers Union says it will investigate whether hazardous conditions are to blame for the death.

image.title: GettyImages-1089479644.jpg
image.alt: Officials say the worker collapsed around 3:10 a.m. Wednesday.
image.caption: Officials say the worker collapsed around 3:10 a.m. Wednesday.

related_authors.biography: Phil Corso is the evening news editor at WNYC/Gothamist. Got a tip? Email pcorso@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: FDNY reports 67% drop in lithium-ion battery deaths in 2024
items.description: Deaths linked to lithium-ion battery fires fell from 18 in 2023 to six in 2024, the FDNY said.

image.title: GettyImages-1471713418.jpg
image.alt: Fire officials and others gather outside of a Bronx supermarket the day after a 5-alarm fire tore through a market that fire officials are blaming on a faulty lithium-ion battery on March 6, 2023.
image.caption: Fire officials and others gather outside of a Bronx supermarket the day after a 5-alarm fire tore through a market that fire officials are blaming on a faulty lithium-ion battery on March 6, 2023.

related_authors.biography:
Giulia Heyward is a breaking news reporter on the Day-Of desk. She previously worked at NPR, as a breaking news reporter, and the New York Times, as a reporting fellow on the national desk. Her work has also appeared in CNN, The Atlantic and Politico. 

Got a tip? Email gheyward@nypublicradio.org or more securely on signal at 917-715-1458.

items.title: In first days of congestion pricing, New Yorkers see signs of reduced gridlock
items.description: Experts warn it's too early to tell what impact the tolls are having on Manhattan's notorious gridlock, but the view from the streets shows signs the program could be working.

image.title: IMG_2706.JPG
image.alt: A view of First Avenue in Midtown East.
image.caption: First Avenue in Midtown East looked unusually calm on Wednesday, Jan. 8.

related_authors.biography: Liam Quigley is a reporter covering parks & sanitation for Gothamist and WNYC. Got a tip? Email lquigley@wnyc.org

Stephen Nessen covers transportation. Since 2008 he has reported on everything from Occupy Wall Street, the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, Hurricane Sandy, to Trump’s campaign for president. His transportation reporting has taken him everywhere from the MTA’s secret Rail Control Center to the gleaming subways of Seoul. Got a tip? Email snessen@wnyc.org.

items.title: NY AG warns Medicaid transportation companies to ‘cease and desist’ fraudulent practices
items.description: Notices went out to 54 companies across the state that the attorney general's office contends are defrauding Medicaid.

image.title: GettyImages-2192987470.jpg
image.alt: New York Attorney General Letitia James speaks during a press conference Wednesday in New York City. James spoke about new measures to stop transportation companies from using fake billing schemes to steal from Medicaid and vulnerable patients. The attorney general issued cease and desist notices to 54 transportation companies throughout the state.
image.caption: New York Attorney General Letitia James speaks during a press conference Wednesday in New York City. James spoke about new measures to stop transportation companies from using fake billing schemes to steal from Medicaid and vulnerable patients. The attorney general issued cease and desist notices to 54 transportation companies throughout the state.

related_authors.biography: Caroline Lewis is on the health care beat for WNYC and Gothamist. She has covered COVID, a nurses' strike, the overdose crisis and New York’s marijuana legalization effort, and spent a year investigating patients' medical bills. She always wants to hear about how everyday New Yorkers experience the health system. Got a tip? Email clewis@wnyc.org.

items.title: Extra Extra: This skinny spaghetti makes angel hair look like bucatini
items.description: Because who wouldn't want to stay in the "Breaking Bad" house, here are your afternoon links: Lure in Soho could close this year, incarcerated workers could get a pay raise this year, the Rangers are slumpin' and more.

image.title: spaghetti.jpg
image.credit: Roberto Machado Noa/LightRocket via Getty Images

items.title: Turkish consulate at heart of Mayor Adams indictment still lacks crucial safety approvals
items.description: A new report from the city comptroller found a “staggering” number of buildings missing required permits, but the Turkish House was the only one of its size approved to open without a valid fire safety plan.

image.title: GettyImages-1791866259.jpg
image.alt: The newly constructed Turkish consulate building stands opposite the United Nations on November 13, 2023 in New York City. An ongoing investigation by the FBI is looking into whether New York City Mayor Eric Adams received campaign money from the Turkish government after reports that he allegedly pressured city fire officials and others to approve the building despite numerous safety concerns. (Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images)
image.caption: The newly constructed Turkish consulate building stands opposite the United Nations on November 13, 2023 in New York City. An ongoing investigation by the FBI is looking into whether New York City Mayor Eric Adams received campaign money from the Turkish government after reports that he allegedly pressured city fire officials and others to approve the building despite numerous safety concerns. (Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images)

related_authors.biography: David is a reporter covering housing for Gothamist and WNYC. Got a tip? Email dbrand@nypublicradio.org or Signal 908-310-3960.
